questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.

questions.text: A team of climbers is being briefed about the physiological changes that occur in the body at high altitudes. Which of the following is NOT a typical physiological response seen in individuals at high altitudes?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoventilation is not a typical response at high altitude. In fact, the opposite occurs - hyperventilation, or increased breathing rate, is a normal physiological response to high altitude to compensate for reduced oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycythemia: Polycythemia, an increase in the number of red blood cells, is a common response to high altitude. It occurs as a compensatory mechanism to improve oxygen carrying capacity due to lower oxygen availability in the atmosphere.

 

Option B. Increase in Hemoglobin (Hb) concentration: An increase in hemoglobin concentration is also a typical response to high altitude. This adaptation helps to enhance the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option C. Increase in myoglobin: There is an increase in myoglobin in muscle tissues at high altitudes. Myoglobin helps in storing oxygen in muscle cells, aiding adaptation to the lower oxygen environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high altitudes, physiological responses include polycythemia, increased hemoglobin concentration, and increased myoglobin, but not hypoventilation.

questions.text: In a community of 100000 population, 105 children were born in a year, out of which 5 were still births and 2 died within 6 months after birth and another 2 died within next 6 months. The IMR (Infant Mortality Rate) is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 40

 

Explanation:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated by dividing the total number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) by the total number of live births, and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

In this case, the given information is:

 

  • Total births in a year = 105
  • Stillbirths = 5
  • Infant deaths within the first 6 months = 2
  • Infant deaths within the next 6 months = 2

 

To calculate the IMR:

 

1. Calculate the number of live births:

Total live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Total live births = 105 - 5 = 100

 

2. Calculate the total number of infant deaths:

Total infant deaths = Infant deaths within the first 6 months + Infant deaths within the next 6 months

Total infant deaths = 2 + 2 = 4

 

3. Calculate the IMR using the formula:

IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) × 1,000

IMR = (4 / 100) × 1,000

IMR = 40

Therefore, the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for this community is 40 per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a crucial indicator that represents the number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population or community.

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NTD

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings typically associated with neural tube defects (NTD), more specifically spina bifida.

 

  • Banana sign: This refers to the excessive curvature of the cerebellum, which appears compressed and curved, resembling a banana.
  • Lemon sign: This is characterized by the pinching of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, causing it to appear like a lemon when viewed from the front. These signs are indicative of the changes in intracranial pressure and structure caused by spina bifida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: This condition involves the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, and is often described as having a "frog-like" face due to the absence of the cranial vault.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome has various ultrasound markers, but these are typically subtle and referred to as soft tissue markers, not including the banana or lemon signs.

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: This condition is characterized by the "double bubble" sign on ultrasound, indicating a blockage in the duodenum, and is not associated with the banana or lemon signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: A person with history of RTA admitted in hospital. He is able to understand what his friend is talking but he is unable to speak. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured in this case? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Broca's area

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient is able to understand spoken language but is unable to speak, indicating that comprehension is intact while fluency is impaired. This condition is characteristic of Broca's aphasia, which results from damage to Broca's area in the frontal lobe of the brain.

 

Broca's area is responsible for speech production and language processing. Damage to this area leads to non-fluent aphasia, where the patient struggles to form words and sentences despite understanding spoken language. This condition is often seen in individuals who have experienced a stroke or traumatic brain injury.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension. The patient would not understand spoken language.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus: Damage to the angular gyrus typically results in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: acalculia (difficulty with calculations), agraphia (difficulty writing), right-left confusion, and finger agnosia.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus causes conduction aphasia, where the patient has intact comprehension and fluency but cannot repeat words or phrases.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Broca's area damage results in Broca's aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production with intact comprehension.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty breathing and  fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

The condition depicted in the provided X-ray, along with the clinical findings of distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds, and symptoms of difficulty breathing and fatigue, is suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Here's an explanation of each condition considered in the differential diagnosis:

 

 This is a critical condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, exerting pressure on the heart, thereby impeding its ability to fill properly during diastole. The classical clinical triad includes distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds, and hypotension (Beck's triad). The X-ray may show an enlarged cardiac silhouette, known as a "water bottle" heart, due to the accumulation of fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial Asthma: This is primarily a pulmonary condition characterized by episodes of breathing difficulty due to reversible airway obstruction, inflammation, and bronchospasm. Typical radiographic findings in asthma include hyperinflation of the lungs, but it would not typically cause distended neck veins or muffled heart sounds.

 

Option C. Constrictive Pericarditis: This chronic condition involves thickening or calcification of the pericardium, which leads to restricted cardiac filling. Symptoms might overlap with those of cardiac tamponade, such as fatigue and elevated neck veins, but the heart sounds are not typically muffled. Radiographic findings might show pericardial calcifications, and the heart size might not be as dramatically enlarged as in tamponade.

 

Option D. Atrial Myxoma: This is a type of primary heart tumor that usually arises in the atria. It can intermittently obstruct blood flow and may lead to varied symptoms based on its size and location. An X-ray might not be diagnostic except for showing general cardiac enlargement.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening emergency which looks like ‘ water bottle heat’ on x-ray and  that requires immediate intervention, typically pericardiocentesis, to relieve the pressure on the heart. Any patient presenting with the classic triad of tamponade and signs consistent on imaging should be managed with urgent care to stabilize the condition and prevent cardiac arrest.

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VIPoma

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, and Achlorhydria), which is characteristic of a VIPoma. VIPomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to the clinical features described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulinoma: Insulinomas typically present with hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin secretion, not with watery diarrhea or hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: These tumors can be non-functional or present with inhibitory syndrome, which includes hyperglycemia, cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea, but not with watery diarrhea and hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Glucagonoma: These tumors present with hyperglycemia, diabetes, and a characteristic rash known as necrolytic migratory erythema (NME), rather than the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIPomas cause WDHA syndrome, characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar joint is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syndesmosis

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint where the radius and ulna are connected along their shafts by an interosseous membrane. This type of joint, where the bones are joined by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue, is classified as a syndesmosis. This allows for some movement between the bones while still providing a strong connection.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symphysis: A symphysis is a type of cartilaginous joint where the bones are joined by fibrocartilage. This is not applicable to the middle radioulnar joint, which is connected by fibrous tissue rather than cartilage.

 

Option B. Synostosis: Synostosis refers to a condition where two bones fuse together, which is not the case with the middle radioulnar joint. This joint maintains a fibrous connection between the bones, not a bony fusion.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: A synchondrosis is a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. This type of joint is typically found in growth plates, not in the middle radioulnar joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is classified as a syndesmosis, which is a type of fibrous joint connected by a sheet of fibrous tissue, such as the interosseous membrane.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

 

INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: A man comes to the OPD with complaints of sinusitis and breathing difficulty. He also gives a history of infertility for the past few years. On further examination, thoracic cavity organs were found to be on the opposite side. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome


Kartagener syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (a condition where the thoracic and abdominal organs are mirrored from their normal positions).

 

The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a defect in the structure and function of cilia, which are hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and other parts of the body. These cilia are responsible for moving mucus and other substances along the respiratory tract, as well as for ensuring proper placement of organs during embryonic development.

 

In this case, the patient's symptoms of sinusitis, breathing difficulties, and history of infertility, combined with the finding of situs inversus, strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome. The infertility is due to immotile sperm in males, which is also caused by defective cilia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: This condition typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness. It is not associated with situs inversus or infertility.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not associated with situs inversus, sinusitis, or bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Although it can cause chronic cough and sinusitis, it is not associated with situs inversus or infertility. Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently widened, leading to frequent lung infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility, all of which result from defective ciliary function.

choices.text: Hydrogen peroxide
Methyl paraben
Bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not a sanitizer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Process of bringing down levels of pathogenic organisms on inanimate surfaces to reduce the chances of cross-infection is called as sanitization.

 

Process of destroying all pathogenic organisms is called as disinfection.

 

Process of eliminating all microorganisms in both vegetative and spore state are eliminated from a surface or medium is called as sterilization.

 

Hydrogen peroxide works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack membrane lipids, DNA, and other essential cell components. Catalase, produced by aerobic organisms and facultative anaerobes that possess cytochrome systems, can protect cells from metabolically produced hydrogen peroxide by degrading hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. This defense is overwhelmed by the concentrations used for disinfection.

 

Disinfection or sterilization of cystoscopes, endoscopes, tubing’s, and metal instruments can be done with liquid form of hydrogen peroxide while gaseous form can be used for fogging. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Penicillin, an antibiotic. It is neither a disinfectant nor a sanitizer.

 

Option C. Methyl paraben is a type of paraben. Parabens are chemicals that are often used as preservatives to give products a longer shelf life.

 

Option D. Household bleaching powder (sodium hypochlorite) is used as a disinfectant in hospitals. Diluted solutions can be used for sanitizing surfaces.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydrogen peroxide is used as a disinfectant because it effectively destroys a wide range of pathogenic organisms. It is not typically used as a sanitizer, which is a process aimed at reducing, rather than completely eliminating, pathogenic organisms on surfaces.

questions.text: A lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parietal lobe

 

A lesion in the parietal lobe can lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination. The parietal lobe is responsible for integrating sensory information from various modalities, including vision and touch, to create a unified perception of the body and its surroundings. It also plays a crucial role in spatial awareness and motor control.

 

In particular, the parietal lobe contains the somatosensory cortex, which is responsible for processing tactile information from the body. This information is used to create a map of the body in space, which is used to guide movement and hand-eye coordination. Damage to the parietal lobe can disrupt these processes, leading to deficits in hand-eye coordination and other motor functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal lobe: Primarily involved in motor control, decision-making, and problem-solving, but not specifically in integrating sensory information for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option C. Temporal lobe: Involved in auditory processing, memory, and language comprehension, not directly in hand-eye coordination.

 

Option D. Occipital lobe: Responsible for visual processing but does not integrate this with sensory-motor functions required for hand-eye coordination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parietal lobe is essential for hand-eye coordination due to its role in integrating sensory information and spatial awareness, guiding movements accurately in response to visual stimuli.

questions.text: A patient presents with following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

The provided image displays clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base, indicative of a possible diagnosis of genital herpes caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

Tzanck smear:

 

  • To perform a Tzanck smear, scrapings are obtained from the lesions, preferably from the base of the vesicles.
  • Smears are then prepared and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds, which allows the visualization of acantholytic and multinucleated giant cells.
  • In Herpes infections, Tzanck smear examination may reveal the presence of Tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

 

Below image depicts Acantholytic cells

 

 

Below image depicts multinucleated giant cells

 

 

  • Tzanck or Acantholytic cells are formed as a result of acantholysis, which is the breakdown of intercellular connections, like desmosomes.
  • This process leads to a reduction in cohesiveness among keratinocytes.

 

Acantholysis is classified as:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Henderson Patterson bodies:

 

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in cells infected with molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus.
  • This is not consistent with the lesion shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Herpes simplex virus infections, scrapings from lesions may show both Acantholytic / Tzanck cells and Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs).

 

Ref - Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 474-476

questions.text: Which of the following comes under ASA grade 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Healthy patient

 

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is a system used to assess the fitness of patients before surgery. It classifies patients into six different categories based on their overall health:

 

  • ASA 1: A Normal, healthy patient with no systemic disease and no significant medical problems.
  • ASA 2: A patient with mild systemic disease that does not limit physical activity (e.g., mild asthma or controlled hypertension).
  • ASA 3: A patient with severe systemic disease that limits activity but is not incapacitating (e.g., uncontrolled diabetes or hypertension).
  • ASA 4: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (e.g., unstable angina, advanced COPD).
  • ASA 5: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without surgery (e.g., massive trauma, ruptured aneurysm).
  • ASA 6: A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

 

In this classification, ASA grade 1 is designated for a healthy patient with no significant medical problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mild disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 2 patient, who has a mild systemic disease that is under control and does not significantly impact their overall health.

 

Option C. Moderate disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 3 patient, who has a moderate to severe systemic disease that limits their activity.

 

Option D. Morbid patient: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 5 patient, who is moribund and at a high risk of death without surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:


ASA grade 1 refers to a normal, healthy patient with no comorbidities or systemic diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graph D

 

Explanation:

 

The normal response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is depicted by Graph D. During an OGTT, a patient ingests a specified amount of glucose (commonly 75 grams), and blood glucose levels are measured at intervals to evaluate how well the body handles glucose. In a normal response:

 

  • Blood glucose levels rise to a peak within 1 hour after ingestion.
  • Glucose levels then decline and return to baseline by 2 hours.
  • The glucose levels do not exceed the renal threshold at any point during the test.

 

This pattern reflects the body's effective regulation of blood glucose levels and the normal function of insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graph A: Graph A might depict an abnormal glucose tolerance curve, such as one seen in impaired glucose tolerance or gestational diabetes, where glucose levels remain elevated for a prolonged period or fail to return to baseline.

 

Option B. Graph B: Graph B could show a response with an abnormal peak or delayed return to baseline, indicative of glucose intolerance or a diagnostic criterion for diabetes mellitus.

 

Option C. Graph C: Graph C might represent an exaggerated glucose peak or prolonged elevated glucose levels, suggesting a pathological glucose tolerance response consistent with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal OGTT response features a peak in blood glucose levels within 1 hour, followed by a return to baseline levels within 2 hours, without exceeding the renal threshold.

 

Ref: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301045468_VARIANTS_OF_ORAL_GLUCOSE_TOLERANCE_TEST_OGTT_CURVE_IN_GESTATIONAL_DIABETES_MELLITUS_GDM

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome which is associated with severe pain; hence the most likely diagnosis here would be herpes zoster or shingles.
  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This is a viral infection of the skin that causes small, pearly, or flesh-coloured bumps. The lesions are typically umbilicated, meaning they have a small indentation or dimple at the centre as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Option D. Lymphangioma circumscriptum: This condition presents as vesicles filled with lymphatic fluid as shown in the image below. It typically does not have the painful, dermatomal distribution seen in herpes zoster.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Which joint is not formed by the bone shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: Patient after road traffic accident was brought to the emergency. His pulse rate was 50 beats per minute, blood pressure was 80/60 mm of Hg. On evaluation his ECG was normal, eFAST was negative, and chest X-ray was normal. This status of the patient could be best classified under which type of shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurogenic shock

 

Explanation

 

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock resulting from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury, often seen in trauma cases like road traffic accidents. This leads to hypotension due to vasodilation and bradycardia due to unopposed vagal tone.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic shock: Characterized by tachycardia and clinical signs of bleeding. The normal eFAST and chest X-ray, along with bradycardia, make this unlikely.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: Expected to show ECG changes and usually presents with tachycardia.

 

Option D. Anaphylactic shock: Typically presents with tachycardia, urticaria, and respiratory symptoms due to allergen exposure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Neurogenic shock should be suspected in trauma patients with hypotension and bradycardia, especially when there is no evidence of hemorrhage or other common shock etiologies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4, E-5
A-1, B-5, C-3, D-2, E-4
A-1, B-2, C-2, D-3, E-4
A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-1, B-5, C-3, D-2, E-4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yolk Sac Tumor is associated with AFP, Choriocarcinoma with Beta hCG, Epithelial Cell Tumor with Ca125, Granulosa Cell Tumor with Inhibin, and Dysgerminoma with LDH.

 

Ref: Page no 521, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

 

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

 

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22m, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42m diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HBeAg: Incorrect, as HBeAg is a Hepatitis B envelope antigen associated with the virus's replication and infectivity but not known as the Australia antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg: Incorrect, HBcAg or Hepatitis B core antigen is associated with the core of the virus but is not referred to as the Australia antigen.

 

Option D. HBV-DNA: Incorrect, this refers to the genetic material of the Hepatitis B virus itself and is not synonymous with the Australia antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 37 weeks. She is a known case of heart disease with a prosthetic valve on warfarin. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to LMWH

 

The patient is a 37-week pregnant woman with a known case of heart disease and a prosthetic valve, currently on warfarin. In pregnant patients with prosthetic heart valves, anticoagulation management is crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications. Warfarin is typically avoided in the late third trimester due to the risk of fetal bleeding and other complications during delivery. It is recommended to switch from warfarin to heparin (usually low molecular weight heparin, LMWH) at around 36 weeks of gestation.

 

Since the patient is still on warfarin at 37 weeks, the immediate action is to switch to LMWH to reduce the risks associated with warfarin during labor and delivery. Before planning an induction of labor (IOL) or cesarean section, heparin should be stopped 12-24 hours before the planned delivery to minimize the risk of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin at this stage is inappropriate because it increases the risk of bleeding for both the mother and the fetus during labor or delivery. Warfarin crosses the placenta and poses significant risks during the peripartum period.

 

Option C. Immediate cesarean: There is no immediate indication for a cesarean section based on her anticoagulation status alone. Cesarean delivery would only be indicated for obstetric reasons. Moreover, performing surgery while the patient is on warfarin increases the risk of severe bleeding complications.

 

Option D. Immediate IOL (Induction of Labor): Immediate induction of labor is not the first step as the patient is still on warfarin, which poses a bleeding risk. Before planning any delivery method, it is essential to switch to heparin and allow a safe window without anticoagulation before proceeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves on warfarin, switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at 36 weeks to reduce the risk of complications during delivery, and stop heparin 12-24 hours before planned delivery.

questions.text: Full form of JSSK is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram


JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was launched in 2005 under the National Rural Health Mission. The older name of JSY was National Maternity Benefit Scheme.

 

Initially, JSY focused only on maternal health, emphasizing the safety and wellbeing of the mother (Janani). However, recognizing the interconnected nature of maternal and newborn health, the program was expanded to include newborn care (Shishu), leading to the creation of JSSK on June 1, 2011 under NRHM. JSSK aims to provide free and cashless services to pregnant women and sick newborns, including transport, medicines, and diet, focusing on enhancing the overall health of both mother and child (upto 1 year of age).

 

Educational Objective:
 

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram, focusing on the protection and care of both the mother and infant by providing comprehensive healthcare services

questions.text: Examination of suspicious stain shows the image below. Which test is this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio

 

The image shows yellow needle-shaped crystals, which are characteristic of the Barberio test. The Barberio test is used to identify the presence of spermine and spermidine, substances commonly found in semen stains. The appearance of yellow needle-shaped crystals is a distinctive feature of this test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence: The Florence test produces dark brown rhombic crystals, not yellow needle-shaped crystals. This test is used to detect choline, another component of semen, and does not match the crystals shown in the image.

 

Option C. Teichmann: Also known as the Hemin test, the Teichmann test is used to confirm the presence of blood and produces dark brown rhombic crystals, similar to the Florence test. It does not produce yellow needle-shaped crystals.

 

Option D. Takayama: The Takayama test, or Hemochromogen test, produces pink feathery crystals. It is used to confirm the presence of blood but is visually distinct from the yellow needle-shaped crystals shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Barberio test is identified by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals and is used for detecting spermine and spermidine in semen stains

questions.text: Which nerve is prone to injury during venesection in a burns patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saphenous nerve

 

Venesection, or phlebotomy, is a procedure where a vein is punctured to withdraw blood or administer fluids. In burns patients, venesection may be more challenging due to damaged skin and underlying tissues. The great saphenous vein is a common site for venesection, especially in the lower limb.

 

The saphenous nerve runs alongside the great saphenous vein in the leg. This close anatomical relationship makes the saphenous nerve particularly vulnerable to injury during venesection in this area. Damage to the saphenous nerve can result in sensory deficits along the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is located in the thigh and supplies motor and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and part of the leg. It is not typically associated with the great saphenous vein and therefore is less likely to be injured during venesection.

 

Option B. Peroneal nerve: The peroneal (or fibular) nerve runs along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and is not in close proximity to the great saphenous vein. It is thus not at significant risk during venesection in the lower limb.

 

Option C. Sural nerve: The sural nerve provides sensory innervation to the posterior and lateral aspects of the leg and foot. It runs alongside the small saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein, so it is less likely to be injured during venesection involving the great saphenous vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, which runs alongside the great saphenous vein, is particularly prone to injury during venesection in a burns patient, especially when accessing the great saphenous vein in the lower limb.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presented in ENT OPD with hoarseness of voice following a quarrel in public. On laryngoscopy, the following picture is seen. Management of this patient is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MLS removal

 

Explanation:

 

The laryngoscopic image shows a unilateral large mass at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is consistent with a vocal polyp. Vocal polyps typically result from vocal abuse or trauma and can cause hoarseness of voice. The definitive management of a vocal polyp is Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS) removal, which involves surgically excising the polyp to restore normal voice function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not indicated for benign lesions such as vocal polyps. It is used primarily for malignant conditions.

 

Option C. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is not a standard treatment for vocal polyps. It is more commonly used for other types of lesions.

 

Option D. Voice rest & Speech therapy: Voice rest and speech therapy are generally recommended for vocal nodules, which are smaller and often bilateral. While these therapies can help in reducing strain on the vocal cords, they are not the primary treatment for vocal polyps, which require surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of a vocal polyp, which presents as a unilateral mass on the vocal cord, is surgical removal via Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS). Voice rest and speech therapy are more suitable for smaller, bilateral vocal nodules.

choices.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.text: 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic TB was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated miliary tuberculosis commonly seen in the elderly population. The term "cryptic" means hidden, indicating that the disease does not present with obvious clinical signs typically associated with TB. This includes a negative skin tuberculin test and no visible evidence of TB on a chest X-ray.

 

Microbiological confirmation of TB in these patients is challenging and often not possible with standard imaging techniques. Modern guidelines suggest using advanced imaging modalities like PET CT scans to detect enlarged lymph nodes in thoracic or abdominal areas, which can be sampled for confirmation. However, even with these methods, microbiological diagnosis is still difficult (DD – Malignancy).

 

In such cases, empirical anti-tubercular treatment is started, and diagnosis is confirmed based on the patient's response to therapy and resolution of symptoms and lymph node enlargement over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB does not typically present with a positive skin tuberculin test or obvious chest X-ray findings. The hidden nature of this form of TB means both tests are likely to be negative.

 

Option C. Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray: Incorrect. As mentioned, cryptic TB results in a negative skin tuberculin test, not a positive one, because the disease does not produce a strong immune response detectable by this test.

 

Option D. Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB is characterized by a lack of clear imaging evidence of TB, making a positive chest X-ray an unlikely finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated tuberculosis common in the elderly, characterized by a negative skin tuberculin test and no obvious imaging evidence of TB. Diagnosis is often confirmed through empirical treatment and advanced imaging techniques.

questions.text: A patient has come to the clinic. Identify the movement being examined in the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction

 

The image provided depicts a clinical examination known as the Trendelenburg test. This test is used to assess the strength and function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. These muscles, innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, stabilize the pelvis during walking by keeping the pelvis level when one leg is lifted off the ground.

 

 

In a normal Trendelenburg test, when the patient stands on one leg, the gluteus medius and minimus on the standing leg contract to elevate the pelvis on the opposite side, maintaining balance. If the superior gluteal nerve is damaged or the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Adduction refers to the movement of a limb toward the midline of the body. This is not the movement being assessed in the Trendelenburg test.

 

Option B. Extension: Extension is the straightening movement that increases the angle between body parts, such as straightening the leg at the hip joint. The Trendelenburg test does not assess extension.

 

Option C. Flexion: Flexion refers to bending a joint, decreasing the angle between body parts. The Trendelenburg test is not assessing flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of these muscles, often due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensory aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms suggest that he is experiencing a type of aphasia where comprehension is impaired, but speech remains fluent. This is characteristic of sensory aphasia (also known as receptive aphasia or fluent aphasia).

 

  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia): Patients with Wernicke's aphasia can speak fluently but their speech often lacks meaning and they have significant difficulty understanding spoken language. They may produce nonsensical and made-up words. This type of aphasia is typically due to a lesion in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area).

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia): This is a non-fluent aphasia where patients have good comprehension but struggle to produce speech. Speech is typically halting and effortful, and patients may be able to produce only short phrases. This is not consistent with the fluent speech described in the case.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Patients with anomic aphasia primarily have difficulty naming objects but otherwise have intact comprehension and fluency. This does not align with the patient’s production of nonsensical words.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This type is characterized by good comprehension and fluent speech, but patients have significant difficulty with repetition. The primary issue in conduction aphasia is the disconnection between comprehension and speech production areas, typically due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This does not fully explain the nonsensical speech observed in the patient.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Sensory aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension, fitting the described symptoms in this patient.

choices.text: Tingling and numbness in peripheral areas

questions.text: Following are the features of Stage of excitement of cocaine except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine bugs

 

Cocaine bugs/Magnan’s Syndrome is a type of hallucination (Formication) seen in cocaine addicts (Chronic Poisoning). Whereas, stage of excitement is seen in acute cocaine poisoning.

 

 

 

Cocaine is obtained from leaves of Erythroxylum cocoa

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeling of well-being: Common in the excitement phase of acute cocaine poisoning.

 

Option C. Tingling and numbness in peripheral areas: A known effect due to local anesthetic properties of cocaine.

 

Option D. Dilated pupil: Cocaine causes mydriasis (dilation of pupils), often seen in the excitement stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine bugs (formication) are associated with chronic cocaine use and hallucinations, whereas the features listed for the excitement stage of acute cocaine poisoning include euphoria, numbness, and dilated pupils but not formication.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopic image of the lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-COV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand which of the labelled layers? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A  

 

The image given in the question demonstrates the electron microscopic image of the blood-air barrier in the lungs. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has been set in this patient with COVID-19. Damage to the endothelial (Labelled as A, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

 

 

 

The electron micrograph shows at high magnification three components of the air-blood barrier in the alveolar septum. Gaseous exchange occurs across, 1) the cytoplasm of a type I alveolar cell or pneumocyte, P1; 2) the fused basal laminas (basement membranes) of type I alveolar and endothelial cells, BM; and 3) the cytoplasm of an endothelial cell, E, enclosing a blood capillary. Note the erythrocyte, Er, present within the lumen of the blood capillary. A fourth component of the air-blood barrier, surfactant, is not preserved in routine histological sections.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basement Membrane: While the basement membrane is part of the blood-air barrier, it is not the primary site of injury in ARDS.

 

Option C. Type I Alveolar cell/Pneumocyte: Although these cells are affected in ARDS, the endothelial cells are typically the first to be damaged.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte: The erythrocyte is not structurally affected by ARDS but rather suffers the consequences of impaired gas exchange due to endothelial and alveolar damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, especially in cases associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection, the primary injury occurs in the endothelial cells of the blood-air barrier, leading to inflammation, increased permeability, and subsequent respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • In the context of penetrating trauma, especially with evisceration (protrusion of internal tissues or organs through a wound), an emergency laparotomy becomes the procedure of choice to address any potential life-threatening injuries, stop bleeding, and repair damaged structures.
  • Evisceration is an indicator of full-thickness injury to the abdominal wall and potential underlying organ damage.

 

Indications for emergency laparotomy in penetrating trauma include:

 

  • Unstable patient
  • Features of peritonitis
  • Evisceration
  • Gunshot wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone in this scenario would delay necessary intervention and could worsen the patient's outcome. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to manage the evisceration and associated internal injuries.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydration: While IV hydration might be a part of the supportive care for a trauma patient, it is not the primary treatment for an evisceration injury. The priority would be to address the traumatic injury directly through surgery.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach, like observation, is passive and is not suitable for traumatic injuries that are obviously severe, like evisceration. Delay in surgical intervention could lead to complications and worsen the patient's prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: The 20-year-old young female presented to the OPD with the following forehead lesions. Which of the following methods won't help with the treatment of various stages of this condition? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical fluocinolone

 

The patient's age and the presence of comedones on the face are suggestive of acne. With the exception of topical fluocinolone (a topical steroid), all of the aforementioned treatments are effective for treating acne. Regardless of how they are administered (Topical or oral).

 

Topical fluocinolone is a corticosteroid. While it may reduce inflammation, its use is not recommended for acne as it can exacerbate the condition, potentially causing acneiform eruption or steroid acne. Steroids can also lead to skin thinning and other adverse effects when used on the face for extended periods.

 

  • Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne,
  • They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.
  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedones or whitehead.
  • When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air & turns black which is known as open comedones (blackhead).

 

Stages of acne:

 

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical benzoyl peroxide:

 

  • This is a commonly used treatment for acne. Its mechanism of action includes reducing Propionibacterium acnes (a bacteria contributing to acne) colonization and producing an oxidizing effect which reduces inflammation.
  • It is effective and is commonly used either alone or in combination with other treatments.

 

Option C. Topical tazarotene:

 

  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid. Retinoids are vitamin A derivatives that help unclog pores by promoting the shedding of dead skin cells from the surface of the skin and reducing inflammation.
  • They are effective in treating both non-inflammatory and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotics:

 

  • These help in reducing the P. acnes bacterial count, which subsequently reduces inflammation.
  • Commonly used topical antibiotics include clindamycin and Nadifloxacin.
  • They may be used alone or in combination with other agents, such as benzoyl peroxide, to reduce bacterial resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical fluocinolone, a corticosteroid, can reduce inflammation, but it is not recommended for acne treatment as it can exacerbate the condition.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1-90.37

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. According to King's College Criteria for predicting mortality in Acute Liver Failure (ALF), which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

 

Explanation: 

 

King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.

 

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.

 

Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.

 

Option B. PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.

 

Option C. Bilirubin >300 µmol/L: An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 µmol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

King's College Criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure include specific parameters such as prolonged PT, elevated bilirubin, and specific age groups. The duration of jaundice before the development of encephalopathy is significant if it exceeds 7 days. Jaundice for less than 7 days is not a parameter for transplantation.

choices.text: Ubiquitination of proteins
Protein modification
Protein folding
Protein cleavage

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein folding

 

Option C. Protein folding

 

  • True. Chaperones play a crucial role in assisting proteins in achieving their correct three-dimensional folded structure. They help prevent misfolding, aggregation, or denaturation of proteins, ensuring their functional conformation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ubiquitination of proteins

 

  • False. Chaperones do not assist in ubiquitination of proteins. Ubiquitination is a process by which a small protein called ubiquitin is added to target proteins to mark them for degradation. Chaperones have a different role in protein biology.

 

Option B. Protein modification

 

  • Partially true. Chaperones are primarily involved in protein folding rather than direct protein modification. However, proper protein folding is essential for their biological function, and chaperones help ensure proteins achieve their correct three-dimensional structure during or after synthesis.

 

Option D. Protein cleavage

 

  • False. Chaperones are not involved in protein cleavage. Protein cleavage typically refers to the enzymatic process of cutting proteins into smaller fragments, which is different from the role of chaperones in facilitating proper folding.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chaperones help to produce the correct spatial arrangement. Chaperones attach to nascent polypeptide chains and prevent wrong folding; so that folding is allowed only in the correct direction. They help in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins.

 

Examples of chaperones are a large family of proteins called heat shock proteins (HSPs). Any stress to the cell including heat, toxins, heavy metals, free radicals, radiation, bacteria, etc. will cause increased production of HSPs, and hence they are more correctly termed as stress proteins.

 

Improper protein folding may lead to prion diseases.
